Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EHR-Polar DCL: Addressing the Technical and Narrative Challenges in the Undergraduate Science Classroom
Award.AbstractNarration: Researchers at the University of Delaware (UD) and at Colgate University will revise and implement a course on polar science in the media. The course will equip students with the technical skills, including computer programming skills taught using a pair-programming approach, to evaluate geoscience data reported in the media and will place this data within a personal context using narratives that convey scientific information. Over the course of the project, ~100 non-geoscience major students will be immersed in a student-centered, data-driven course. Evaluations will focus on improving students' ability to analyze and understand the implications of data and on the transferability of the course materials to different institutions. The impact of this project will extend well beyond the award period through continued offerings at UD and Colgate University, by distributing the course and pedagogy content through the NSF-sponsored Science Education Resource Center (SERC) as the primary conduit to geoscience educators and through professional development workshops offered to new and existing geoscience instructors at major geoscience conferences. <br/><br/>A new polar science course for non-STEM majors will be designed and implemented. The course is based on a combination of cognitivism and constructivism and with quantitative metrics for assessing student progress on technical and narrative challenges. Evaluations will address the hypothesis that student exposure to a pair-programming pedagogy will improve their technical data access and interpretation skills and the hypothesis that students exposed to developed narrative structure exercises will demonstrate improved perspective-taking skills and will be able to demonstrate better understanding the narrative context in which the data are presented. The project is co-funded by the Office of Polar Programs and the Division of Undergraduate Education.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polar environments are key indicators of global climate change. That’s why Earth’s poles a central topic in geoscience education and a popular subject for science news coverage. However, students and members of the public face challenges developing the quantitative and computer-aided analysis skills needed to access and evaluate new geoscience data. This is especially true because many news story readers also face recognizing the broader “story behind the story” that shapes how science news is presented. In other words, are there narratives or stories that might shape how two different people could interpret the same scientific data to mean two very different things? To help address both the data analysis challenge and the storytelling challenge, we designed and implemented a novel undergraduate geoscience course designed to strengthen both quantitative and narrative skills through team-based “pair programming” exercises and discussions. The newly-improved course included both the original pair programming class activities from the original Oceans in the New course, as well as two new modules related to permafrost and Earth’s carbon budget. We offered this course at both the University of Delaware and Colgate University and compared student skill growth to two “control” geosciences courses that traditional lecture-based class tools. We measured scientific and narrative skill growth using before-and-after tests that included a data analysis challenge and before-and-after surveys related to interpersonal perspective taking.

Overall, we found that students in the experimental classes became more adept at analyzing scientific data than students in the control classes. Interestingly, we found that results were not even across institutions—students made the most clear learning gains at Colgate, with students at the University of Delaware showing more mixed results. Students became more proficient at accessing data, making graphs, and then verbally describing the graphs and their significance in a short paragraph caption.

Our project recognizes the importance of narratives that convey scientific information. Overall, our surveys suggested that students’ perspectives on their relationships to others did not change greatly as a result of the experimental course. Students were not likely to change their answers in response to survey questions like, “How much would you agree or disagree that you find it difficult to see things from another’s point of view?” This is surprising, because in focus groups held after the classes, students reported that interacting with both the science data and the personal stories behind the science helped them see the world better from someone else’s point of view. The could see how peoples’ backgrounds or prior experiences could shape how they would react to learning new scientific information.

What was perhaps the most striking outcome of the project was hearing from students how much they had learned about the scientific process and the tools of coding. This was especially notable because these courses were designed for students not majoring in science fields. Many students reported that they would have felt intimidated by a class about coding, or that they would never have signed up for a class that more directly advertised that it was about data analysis. But they reported that by learning to code and analyze science data through the pair programming activities, and by learning about the stories behind the science, they felt motivated and empowered to learn how to analyze the scientific datasets. They came to see how the science results fueled a story about the environmental issues they cared about. This suggests that the pair programming activities designed and tested by this project, and the combination of scientific and storytelling analyses, provided exciting new approaches for helping students develop new, quantitative, career-readying skills even among students who might otherwise feel reluctant or nervous about learning technical skillsets.

The project not only helped students learn, but also provided direct and indirect opportunities for professional development of geosciences university faculty, expanding the opportunities for learning the pair programming technique and the for applying the technique to teaching about environmental processes. Professors anywhere can now access and implement all the modules through the SERC website. In addition, two junior faculty members (one female professor at University of Delaware and one male professor at Colgate) benefitted from direct professional development and growth in learning how to design and implement experimental classes for learning research.
